00046 template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
00047 class Driver
00048 {
00049 private:
00051   TcalcEngine calculator;
00053   Tstore storage;
00055   Parameters myParameters;
00057   Wrapper<SwRandoms::RandomBase2> randomGenerator;
00058   
00059 public:
00060   Driver();
00061   ~Driver();
00067   int Setup( std::string resume, std::string inputFile );
00069   void SetParameters( Parameters &myParameters );
00071   void RunOneIteration();

00074 };

00077 Driver<TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms>::Driver()
00078   : myParameters( "Opacity3" )
00079 {
00080   // Nothing to do on creation, most setup done by the Setup() function
00081   // so that errors on setup can be understood
00082 
00083   // The only thing is the constructor of myParameters,
00084   // to tell it that the version of this program is Opacity version 3
00085   // TODO: make the 'Opacity3' section describe all necessary parts of the program
00086   // for a compatible read in / out
00087 }

00095 template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
00096 int Driver<TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms>::Setup( std::string resume, std::string inputFile )
00097 {
00098   // Function to do all necessary run time setup of objects
00099   // TODO: give a meaningful return code, so if this fails the program quits
00100 
00101   // The runtime settings are read in from a file with a specific format
00102   // This format is governed by the 'Parameters' object, see there for specifics
00103 
00104   // First, read in the file into the object
00105   // If we are resuming from a previous run, the parameters have been written to the
00106   // end of the file, and the Parameters objects can find them there
00107   // All the tokens in the file are read into a 'map'
00108   myParameters.ParseInputFile( inputFile );
00109 
00110   // Pass the parameters object to each object in turn
00111   // First, this one, the driver
00112   SetParameters( myParameters );
00113   // Second, the storage object - eg for size of each dimensions, number of points etc 
00114   storage.SetParameters( myParameters );
00115   // Third, the calculation object - eg GLV specific params, mu, temperature etc
00116   calculator.SetParameters( myParameters );
00117 
00118   // If we are resuming from a previous run, we also need to read in the statistics
00119   // from that run into the data store
00120   if ( resume == "y" )
00121     storage.ReadFromFile( inputFile );
00122 
00123   // Finally, check that all the inputs from the parameters file were used at some point
00124   // Otherwise, the user might think that some parameters are being set that really aren't
00125   int allUsed = myParameters.CheckForUnaccessedParameters();
00126   if ( allUsed != 0 )
00127   {
00128     std::cerr << "Driver::Setup - " << allUsed << " unused parameters from input file.\n";
00129     return 1;
00130   }
00131   else
00132   {
00133     std::cout << "All parameters read successfully from " << inputFile << std::endl;
00134   }
00135 
00136   // TODO: change this so that more errors are detected and so more possible to not
00137   // return 0
00138   return 0;
00139 }
00140 
00141 template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
00142 void Driver<TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms>::SetParameters( Parameters &MyParameters )
00143 {
00144   // Do specific setup for this driver object
00145   // The only settings necessary are for the random number generator
00146   // TODO: clean up the 'Parameters' object, so this doesn't look so convoluted
00147 
00148   std::list<std::string> ReturnedParamsString;
00149   
00150   // The type of random number generator
00151   // Current options are 'Drand48' and 'Sobol'
00152   ReturnedParamsString.empty();
00153   ReturnedParamsString = MyParameters.GetParametersString( "@RandomNumberGenerator" );
00154   
00155   SwRandoms::RandDrand48 ranDrand48( numOfRandoms );
00156   SwRandoms::RandSobol ranSobol( numOfRandoms );
00157 
00158   if ( ReturnedParamsString.front() == "Drand48" )
00159     randomGenerator = ranDrand48;
00160   else if ( ReturnedParamsString.front() == "Sobol" )
00161     randomGenerator = ranSobol;
00162   else
00163   {
00164     //return -1;
00165   }
00166 
00167   // Now that we have set up the type of generator, we need a seed for the
00168   // generator
00169   // TODO: add this as an option to the Parameters object, including the time(NULL) option
00170   //long seed = time(NULL);
00171   long seed = 2;
00172   randomGenerator->SetSeed( seed );
00173 
00174   //return 0;
00175 }
00176 
00177 template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
00178 void Driver<TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms>::RunOneIteration()
00179 {
00180   // The guts of the Monte Carlo calculation
00181   // For one iteration, we fetch in a set of random numbers,
00182   // (these are supplied as a uniform distribution over [0,1)
00183   // then pass this to the calculation object,
00184   // (which will transform them to the required limits)
00185   // then iterate over all the points in the deterministic dimensions,
00186   // getting the calculation result for each point,
00187   // and passing this result to the data store.
00188   // TODO: generalize the iteration over deterministic dimensions to n-dimensions,
00189   // with n chosen as a template parameter to the driver object
00190 
00191   // First, get the array of random numbers
00192   // TODO: change the interface to the random number generator
00193   // to ask / get a fixed size array using boost::array
00194   // At the moment, the change from a boost::array to a std::vector (MyArray)
00195   // is cumbersome / a hack
00196   boost::array<double, numOfRandoms> randomNumbers;
00197   SwArrays::MyArray randomNumbersTmp( numOfRandoms );
00198   randomGenerator->GetUniforms( randomNumbersTmp );
00199   for ( std::size_t i=0; i<numOfRandoms; ++i )
00200     randomNumbers[i] = randomNumbersTmp[i];
00201 
00202   // Pass the random numbers to the calculator object
00203   calculator.SetRandoms( randomNumbers );
00204 
00205   // Now iterate over the deterministic dimensions,
00206   // setting the new coordinate for each point in each dimension,
00207   // getting the answer and adding it to the data store
00208   // TODO: improve, to have arbitrary number of dimensions
00209   std::vector<double> tmp(1);
00210   for (long dim1=0; dim1<storage.GetLengthDim1(); ++dim1)
00211   {
00212     calculator.SetCoord( 1, storage.GetCoordDim1( dim1 ) );
00213 
00214     for (long dim2=0; dim2<storage.GetLengthDim2(); ++dim2)
00215     {
00216       calculator.SetCoord( 2, storage.GetCoordDim2( dim2 ) );
00217       calculator.GetAnswer( tmp );
00218       storage.AddPoint( dim1, dim2, tmp );
00219     }
00220   }
00221 }
00222 
00223 template<typename TcalcEngine, typename Tstore, std::size_t numOfRandoms>
00224 void Driver<TcalcEngine, Tstore, numOfRandoms>::SaveResults( std::string outputFile )
00225 {
00226   // Save the results of our simulation to a permanent file
00227   // We need to include the state of both the data store and
00228   // the input runtime parameters
00229 
00230   // First, send the Store2D to file
00231   // The false here => erase any current contents of the file
00232   storage.WriteToFile( outputFile, false );
00233 
00234   // Now delegate to the params class to output the settings to the end of the file
00235   // In this way, we have a record of what the inputs were, and a way to resume and
00236   // add more statistics if wanted.
00237   // The true here => append to file
00238   myParameters.WriteToFile( outputFile, true );
00239 }
